Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common

Class ObjectMethods

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.naturalis.common.ObjectMethods
  • public class ObjectMethods
extends Object
    General methods applicable to objects of any type.

    Container objects

    Some methods in this class apply special logic (documented on the method itself) when passed a container object. A container object is one of the following

    • an instance of Object[]
    • an instance of Collection
    • an instance of Map
    • an array of primitive values

    For Map objects the logic will always only applied to their values, not their keys. Use Map.keySet() if you want to apply the logic to their keys as well.

    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

        public static boolean isEmpty​(Optional arg)

        Parameters:

      • isEmpty

        public static boolean isEmpty​(Object arg)
        Returns whether or not the specified argument is null or empty. This method is (and can be) used for broad-stroke methods like ifEmpty(Object, Object) and CommonChecks.empty(). Returns true if any of the following applies:

        • arg is null
        • arg is an empty CharSequence
        • arg is an empty Collection
        • arg is an empty Map
        • arg is a zero-length array
        • arg is an empty Optional or an Optional containing an empty object
        • arg is a zero-size Sizeable
        • arg is an empty Emptyable

        Otherwise this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        arg - The argument to check
        Returns:
        Whether or not it is null or empty

      • isNotEmpty

        public static boolean isNotEmpty​(Object arg)
        Verifies that the argument is neither null nor empty. This method is (and can be) used for broad-stroke methods like #ifNotEmpty(Object, Object) and CommonChecks.notEmpty(). Returns true if any of the following applies:

        • obj is a non-empty CharSequence
        • obj is a non-empty Collection
        • obj is a non-empty Map
        • obj is a non-zero-length array
        • obj is a non-empty Optional containing a non-empty object
        • obj is a non-zero-size Sizeable
        • obj is a non-empty Emptyable
        • obj is a non-null object of any other type
        Parameters:
        arg - The object to be tested
        Returns:
        Whether or not it is empty

      • isDeepNotEmpty

        public static boolean isDeepNotEmpty​(Object obj)
        Verifies that the argument is recursively non-empty. Returns true if any of the following applies:

        • obj is a non-empty CharSequence
        • obj is a non-empty Collection containing only deep-not-empty elements
        • obj is a non-empty Map containing only deep-not-empty values (keys are not considered)
        • obj is a non-zero-length Object[] containing only deep-not-empty elements
        • obj is a non-zero-length array of primitives
        • obj is a non-empty Optional containing a deep-not-empty object
        • obj is a non-empty Emptyable
        • obj is a non-zero-size Sizeable
        • obj is a non-null object of any other type
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to be tested
        Returns:
        Whether or not it is recursively non-empty

      • isNoneNull

        public static boolean isNoneNull​(Object arg)
        Verifies that the argument is not null and, if it is a Collection, Map or Object[], does not contain any null values. It may still be an empty collection, map or array, however.
        Parameters:
        arg - The object to be tested
        Returns:
        Whether or not it is not null and does not contain any null values

      • e2n

        public static <T> T e2n​(T arg)
        Empty-to-null: returns null if the argument is empty, else the argument itself.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the argument
        Parameters:
        arg - The argument
        Returns:
        The argument itself if not empty or null

      • e2nEquals

        public static boolean e2nEquals​(Object arg0,
                                Object arg1)
        Tests the provided arguments for equality using empty-equals-null semantics. This is roughly equivalent to Objects.equals(e2n(arg0), e2n(arg1)), except that empty (but non-null) instances of different types (e.g. String and Set) are generally not equal to each other. (An empty HashSet, however, is equal to an empty TreeSet.)

        1. null equals an empty CharSequence
        2. null equals an empty Collection
        3. null equals an empty Map
        4. null equals an empty array
        5. null equals an empty Optional or an Optional containing an empty object
        6. null equals an empty Emptyable
        7. null equals a zero-size Sizeable
        8. A empty intance of one type is not equal to a empty instance of another non-comparable type
        Parameters:
        arg0 - The 1st of the pair of objects to compare
        arg1 - The 2nd of the pair of objects to compare
        Returns:
        Whether or not the provided arguments are equal using empty-equals-null semantics

      • e2nDeepEquals

        public static boolean e2nDeepEquals​(Object arg0,
                                    Object arg1)
        Recursively tests the arguments for equality using empty-equals-null semantics.
        Parameters:
        arg0 - The 1st of the pair of objects to compare
        arg1 - The 2nd of the pair of objects to compare
        Returns:
        Whether or not the provided arguments are deeply equal using empty-equals-null semantics

      • e2nHashCode

        public static int e2nHashCode​(Object obj)
        Generates a hash code for the provided object using using empty-equals-null semantics. Null and empty objects (whatever their type) all have the same hash code: 0 (zero). Therefore a TreeMap or TreeSet using on empty-equals-null semantics may have to fall fall back more often on e2nEquals or e2nDeepEquals.
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to generate a hash code for
        Returns:
        The hash code

      • e2nHash

        public static int e2nHash​(Object... objs)
        Generates a hash code for the provided arguments using using empty-equals-null semantics. See Object.hashCode().
        Parameters:
        objs - The objects to generate a hash code for
        Returns:
        The hash code

      • ifNull

        public static <T> T ifNull​(T value,
                           T dfault)
        Returns the first argument if it is not null, else the second argument. This method will throw an IllegalArgumentException if the second argument is null, so it is guaranteed to return a non-null value.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The input and return type
        Parameters:
        value - The value to return if not null
        dfault - The value to return if the first argument is null
        Returns:
        A non-null value

      • ifNull

        public static <T,​E extends Exception> T ifNull​(T value,
                                                     ThrowingSupplier<T,​E> supplier)
                                              throws E extends Exception
        Returns the first argument if it is not null, else the value supplied by the specified Supplier. The value supplied by the Supplier is guaranteed to be non-null, or else an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The input and return type
        E - The exception potentially being thrown by the supplier as it produces a default value
        Parameters:
        value - The value to return if not null
        supplier - The supplier of a default value if value is null
        Returns:
        a non-null value
        Throws:
        E extends Exception

        Parameters:

        dfault - The value to return if value is null

        Parameters:

      • nullIf

        public static <T> T nullIf​(T arg0,
                           T... values)

          this.operator = nullIf(operator, Operator.AND);
        Type Parameters:

        Parameters:
        arg0 - The value to test
        values - The value it must not have in order to be returned
        Returns:
        value or null

        Parameters:

        values - The values arg0 may have in order to be returned

      • ifNotNull

        public static <T,​U> U ifNotNull​(T arg,
                                      Function<T,​U> then)
        Returns the result of passing the specified argument to the specified Funtion if the argument is not null, else returns null. For example: 
         String[] strs = ifNotNull("Hello World", s -> s.split(" "));
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the first argument
        U - The return type
        Parameters:
        arg - The value to test
        then - The transformation to apply to the value if it is not null
        Returns:
        value or null

      • ifNotNull

        public static <T,​U> U ifNotNull​(T arg,
                                      Function<T,​U> then,
                                      U dfault)
        Returns the result of passing the specified argument to the specified Funtion if the argument is not null, else a default value. For example: 
         String[] strs = ifNotNull("Hello World", s -> s.split(" "), new String[0]);
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the first value to transform
        U - The return type
        Parameters:
        arg - The value to transform
        then - The transformation to apply to the value if it is not null
        dfault - A default value to return if the argument is null
        Returns:
        The result produced by the Function or by the Supplier
